In SCREENAGERS, as with her award-winning documentaries on mental health, physician and filmmaker Delaney Ruston takes a deeply personal approach as she probes into the vulnerable corners of family life, including her own, to explore struggles over social media, video games, academics and internet addiction. Through poignant, and unexpectedly funny stories, along with surprising insights from authors, psychologists, and brain scientists, SCREENAGERS reveals how tech time impacts kidsâ€™ development and offers solutions on how adults can empower kids to best navigate the digital world and find balance. Information about the movie can be found at www.screenagersmovie.com.

post_text: Looking for about 4 parents/guardians from across grade levels who would be willing to participate in a group interview with a team of educators from an outside district who will be conducting something called the Integrated Field Review. This is an Agency of Education accountability process where teams of educators from various districts visit other schools and conduct a very scripted and specific protocol to gather data about school systems. At the end of the process, teams write up a broad report suggesting areas the supervisory union might want to focus on in the future. There is not an individual school report. This group interview would be conducted on February 13th, in the afternoon, in the 2:15-2:45 time frame. Should last about 20 minutes or so. If you would like to volunteer for this, please send me an email and I'll let you know within the next week about specific details. We would so apprecite your insights! smckelvie@gisu.org

post_text: Middle Schoolers in the rain using power tools? What's going on? During the ecology unit in science class, the 7th and 8th graders partnered with the South Hero Land Trust, Guy Maguire, and Emily Alger, to create an Ecology Station for the Water Wigglers Learning Path. On December 21st, in the rain, all of their work came together and the final project was completed. Students were involved with creating the artwork and the literature for the board, the brochure, the on-line field guide, and making the sign its self. Come check out the Ecology Station, to learn more about the food web on the Water Wigglers Learning Path. Thank you to the South Hero Land Trust for this amazing opportunity.

post_text: To anyone who doesn't get a snow day call (either currently or in the future), please let us know. However, even with all of the correct info in the system, it isn't unusual for a percentage of calls to be dropped during a mass call event, such as a day when hundreds of schools are posting snow day announcements. It is called "network congestion." It is more common in rural areas where our cell phone towers are spread far apart and aren't designed to handle large influxes of calls all at once. We don't have any control over this issue. This is why it is a good idea to have a secondary phone on the list, or be sure to check other sources if you suspect we may have a snow day.

post_text: 7th and 8th graders have been learning about Ecology in Science class. This includes population growth, limiting factors, carrying capacity, and symbiotic relationships in different biomes. At the Ed Weed Fish Culture Station in Grand Isle, Vermont, our guide Tom taught us about the different biomes that exist in Lake Champlain and showed us the fish that live there. Tom also explained how the hatchery's main purpose is to replenish the fish population in Lake Champlain, instead of the put-take mission of other hatcheries in the state. Lastly, Tom explained that with a man-made environment there are many more limiting factors that we (the biologist) have to think about in order to keep the survival rate of fish in the high 90%ile. In addition, Tom showed students how the hatchery conserves heat and water loss. We want to thank the South Hero Land Trust for providing busing for this spectacular opportunity.
